simple.util
Class BitArray

java.lang.Object
  simple.util.BitArray

public final class BitArray
extends java.lang.Object

This handles bits of various sizes in a boolean array.
The array size is set when made and cannot grow or shrink.
Created: 2004

Version:
1.0
Author:
Kenneth Pierce

 void toggleAll()

 void toggleBit(long bit)
          Toggles the bit at bit.
For example:
bit = 32 and the bit array = 31+16
When this is called given 32 the bit array now equals 32+31+16.
It stops when the first bit is encountered, so if you give it 7 it will stop at 1.

bits

private final boolean[] bits
Constructor Detail

BitArray

public BitArray()
Creates a BitArray of size 8.

BitArray

public BitArray(BitArray[] b)
Creates a BitArray with a size equal to the sum of the sizes of the BitArrays in the array.
Think of it as the constructor for sub arrays. The value of the array works like so:
b[0].toString() = 00011; b[1].toString() = 100
The new BitArray.toString() = 00011100

Parameters:
b -

BitArray

public BitArray(int size)
Creates a new BitArray with size bits.

Parameters:
size - The number of bits to be used.

BitArray

                long value)
Creates a new BitArray with size bits and sets the value to value.

Parameters:
size - The number of bits to be used.
value - The initial value.

toggleAll

public void toggleAll()
Inverts the current set of bits.

toggleBit

public void toggleBit(long bit)
Toggles the bit at bit.
For example:
bit = 32 and the bit array = 31+16
When this is called given 32 the bit array now equals 32+31+16.
It stops when the first bit is encountered, so if you give it 7 it will stop at 1.

Parameters:
bit - Bit to be toggled.

Returns:

Returns:
